Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Robust Optimization of Rich Vehicle Routing Problems Under Uncertainty

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project considers the utilization of a fleet of vehicles during freight and service delivery operations, and aims to enhance the ability to optimize such processes in view of operational uncertainty, such as uncertainty related to the transportation network (e.g., traffic conditions, road closings or vehicle break-downs), or uncertainty related to the delivery targets themselves (e.g., customer demands, time availabilities, or geographic locations). From a practical perspective, failure to take into account uncertainty when making operational decisions in this context may have significant economic and reputational repercussions for operators, as slight changes in operational conditions may lead even a carefully planned and "optimized" operation to become highly suboptimal or outright infeasible. Furthermore, efficient optimization and risk-management frameworks for vehicle routing operations, such as the one developed in this project, can benefit the environment by reducing unwanted side-effects of delivery systems such as traffic congestion and pollution emissions. In addressing this important issue, this project applies and advances the theoretical field of Robust Optimization (RO), which has emerged in the scientific literature as a promising framework to optimize mathematical models subject to parameter uncertainty. The project seeks to systematize the application of RO in the context of mathematical models used for the optimization of vehicle routing operations and to streamline the adoption of its theoretical and methodological innovations by practitioners. The project further impacts Education by providing training to graduate and undergraduate students on issues of freight and service delivery operations, optimization methods and algorithms, uncertainty quantification and analysis, and scientific computation, as well as enabling STEM outreach to K-12 students.

This project aims to develop an optimization framework for the systematic treatment of uncertainty in rich Vehicle Routing Problems (VRPs). VRPs consider a fleet of vehicles and their optimal utilization in freight and service delivery operations. Rich VRP settings particularly account for complicated operational realities that are answered in practice. From a practical perspective, it is of interest to design freight and service delivery systems that take into account operational uncertainties, since failure to do so may lead to solutions that are infeasible or highly suboptimal. The project applies the Robust Optimization (RO) framework, which has not been considered much in the context of VRPs. The framework seeks to optimize the problem in view of a "worst-case" scenario, as dictated by an uncertainty set that is suitably selected to reflect the decision maker's tolerance for risk and ambiguity. An RO-based approach can be advantageous from a tractability viewpoint and does not require precise distributional knowledge. The expected methodological contributions include the development of (a) robust formulations, cutting planes, and efficient exact solution approaches, (b) robust feasibility checks and efficient metaheuristic solution approaches, and (c) associated uncertainty sets that are tractable, practically relevant, and easily tuned according to risk tolerance. Furthermore, we plan to compile comprehensive collections of new benchmark instances and computational performance profiles, which will help to stimulate research efforts in the area. Efficient rich-VRP optimization and risk-management frameworks, such as the one developed in this project, can have an important impact in the competitiveness, service quality and sustainability of companies that adopt them. Furthermore, they benefit the environment by reducing unwanted side-effects of delivery systems, such as traffic congestion and pollution emissions. The project will further impact Education via providing training to graduate and undergraduate students on issues of freight and service delivery operations, optimization methods and algorithms, uncertainty quantification and analysis, and scientific computation, as well as enabling STEM outreach to K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated advanced methods for the optimization of complex vehicle routing and team orienteering problems with various operational realities, such as operations involving a heterogeneous fleet of vehicles, multiple depots, planning periods of multiple days, cross-docks, endogenous and exogenous time windows among others. For such contexts, various robust optimization methodologies were developed to address uncertainty in customer demands as well as uncertainty in travel and service times. These research activities led to new theoretical results and to the development of novel algorithms, which can be applied for the optimization of systems beyond the scope of this project.

 

Highlight outcomes of this project included:

1. Our work derived new closed-form expressions and numerically efficient ways for verification of robust feasibility for various classes of uncertainty sets, including disjoint and inclusion-constrained budget sets, gamma (cardinality constraint) sets, factor models, ellipsoids and scenario-based (discrete) uncertainty sets. These important theoretical results for treating demand uncertainty appeared for the first time in the vehicle routing literature.

 

2. Our work on local search approaches shows how edge-exchange neighborhood structures can be augmented to efficiently generate candidate routes that are robust, i.e., remain feasible for any postulated demand realization. We further demonstrated how this new robust local search framework can be employed within advanced metaheuristic implementations to generate robust solutions, such as Iterated Local Search (ILS) and Adaptive Memory Programming (AMP), with minimal computational overhead. These results can be transferred to any related robust planning or scheduling problem.

 

3. Our work produced a new integer programming formulation for a broad class of heterogeneous VRPs that models a wide variety of problem variants, as well as a branch-and-cut algorithm to obtain lower bounds on the optimal robust solution. A key feature of the new formulation is a generalization and robustification of the rounded capacity inequality to the heterogeneous fleet setting.

 

4. Our work on the Consistent Vehicle Routing Problem with Profits was the first attempt in the literature to combine the vehicle routing with team orienteering problems over a planning horizon of multiple days with cross-period consistent service constraints.

 

5. Our work produced new theoretical and methodological insights for vehicle routing problems with endogenous time windows (a.k.a. self-imposed time windows) and uncertain travel times. We focused on how to assign flexible and robust time windows under uncertainty and this is the first work in the literature to incorporate service reliability restrictions in this context. Most studies in vehicle routing seek to minimize investment and operating costs, acknowledging only as side issues customer service aspects. For example, a logistics provider may want to quote time windows to a given set of customers such that the expected costs incurred after routing are minimized. Promising a precise service time can be impossible or extremely costly to satisfy due to uncertainties. Our work proposed new ways to treat the disruptions and the uncertain travel (or service) times, and derived new chance constraint models and hierarchical optimization frameworks for single-period problems with self-imposed time windows.

 

6. Our work on Pickup-and-Delivery problems and VRPs with Cross-Docking analyzed the relative effectiveness of direct-shipping and cross-docking strategies. The results indicated that various parameters and network characteristics, and most notably the vehicle capacity, the geographic distribution of the supplier and customer nodes, as well as the supplier-customer pair proximity have a strong impact on the costs incurred by the compared distribution strategies. The new metaheuristic algorithms developed in the context of this project have outperformed most of the current state-of-the-art solutions methods for this class of problems.

 

7. Our work on multi-period orienteering problems produced new upper and lower bounds for various groups of interesting problems with period-dependent availabilities, visit quotas, budget restrictions, duration constraints, and multiple time windows.

 

All innovations were broadly disseminated via journal publications, presentations in international conferences and research seminars. This work also included the engagement of a Ph.D. student at Stevens Institute of Technology and the development of new teaching material for various courses.
